newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn futures close near three-month low.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn futures close near three-month low.

text.p: CBOT corn ended near a three-month low Friday on prospects for good growing weather and technical weakness following Thursday's losses, traders and analysts said.

"It's mostly a little follow-through selling from yesterday," said Jack Scoville, analyst with The Price Group brokerage in Chicago. "People are also blowing out of their positions before the long three-day holiday weekend."
CBOT markets will be closed Monday in observance of the U.S. Memorial Day holiday. Traders often exit positions before long weekends.
Weather outlooks for the Corn Belt show mostly favorable growing and planting conditions, which bodes well for the newly planted crop, traders and analysts said.
Rain is expected in some dry regions of the western Corn Belt and clear and warmer weather has enabled eastern Corn Belt farmers to plant, traders said.
The outlook for good weather throughout the Corn Belt for at least the near term and the prospects for a large crop in the fall have alleviated most supply concerns, traders said.
CBOT corn futures ended 2-3/4 to 4-1/4 cents per bushel lower, with July down 2-3/4 at $2.70-1/2.
On the day, Term Commodities and Goldenberg Hehmeyer each sold five million bushels of December. Cargill sold two million July and one million December.
Prudential Securities bought three million bushels December and one million July, pit sources said.
In options trading, Cargill Investor Services sold 900 December $2.80 calls. FIMAT Futures Inc bought 3,000 July $2.90 puts and sold 1,500 July $2.80 puts, floor sources said.
Corn futures volume was estimated by CBOT at 53,000 contracts, compared with Thursday's actual volume of 54,247 contracts.
